comments.author: Arugulove.wordpress.com
comments.content: This is such a great base.  I've made something similar using pimenton and raisins for a Spanish twist, but now I"m inspired to mix it up a bit.

comments.author: Hana
comments.content: Never had fresh home-cooked chick peas before, but I really want to try them. Sounds like a great way to utilize the last of the veggies in the drawer, which happens to me a lot, so I am always looking for new ways to be creative about it. Looks delicious!

comments.author: Tracy
comments.content: I am so making this for dinner some night soon.

comments.author: Alessandra
comments.content:
Nice and filling, usually i don't pair spinach with tomatoes, but in a soup is OK by me :-)!

ciao
Alessandra

comments.author: Linda
comments.content: I just found your blog and can't wait to read through all your recipes and posts!  This is definitely a soup I would love and improvising is my second name!  Delicious!!

comments.author: Smitty
comments.content: I added chopped zucchini to this soup (only because I had one left over)and it was delish!

comments.author: Mary
comments.content: YUM! This includes all my favorite veggies! I can't wait to try this! Great blog; happy I found you! Mary xo Delightful Bitefuls

comments.author: Morgan
comments.content: Don't you love it when improvisation comes together in something so delicious? Not to mention, the varietal possibilities in this dish are fantastic!

comments.author: todd richardson
comments.content: This was definitely a hit.  It was also good because (combined with the previous carrot soup recipe) I used the pressure cooker twice in one week.  Homemade chickpeas are way better than the canned version.

comments.author: ben
comments.content:
delicious .....

i get so many compliments when i make your recipes!

it did seems like a lot of chickpeas to me though ... not that i don't like them ... and no more cans of chickpeas for me! if i could only remember not to through out the water ....  twice now!

wonderful flavor, will certainly make again, like most of your recipes i try!


thanks so much!

Looking forward to that cookbook!

ben

comments.author: Francie
comments.content: Some of my favorite ingredients all in recipe, I can't wait to try this one out! I am also very impressed that you come up with this on the spot, and for guests too!

comments.author: Runawaycatt
comments.content: I made the quick version of this: canned chickpeas, skipped the pureeing part and added veggie stock. Still very delicious!

comments.author: Erik Galli Lydén
comments.content: Made this the other day, was very hearty and had a nice, kind of "different" flavor! Great student food too, I put a bunch of servings in the freezer for later. :)

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: That one should freeze very well.

comments.author: Sharon Dale
comments.content: Great recipe. I used Swiss chard instead of spinach and a blend of cumin, coriander, pepper and sesame seeds pulverized in a grinder instead of dukkah. Went heavy on the lemon juice. Topped with 50-50 blend of flat leafed parsley and cilantro. Terrific winter soup.

comments.author: Tom Eickenberg
comments.content: I am making this for the third time in three weeks, great meal, I found your sit and intend to use it offten.   I just ordered your cookbook from my local book store, Left Bank Books in Belfast Maine.  Thank you
